importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year of release of 'Diwale Dulhania Le Jayenge' (DDLJ), marking its cultural and cinematic impact in India during a time of economic liberalization and cultural transition.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period of early 1990s economic liberalization in India, when the film captured the nation's cultural awakening, desire for globalization, and tension between tradition and modernity.
The decade following DDLJ's release, during which it influenced a string of future Bollywood films such as 'Pardes', 'Kabhi Khushi Kabhie Gham', and 'Kal Ho Naa Ho'.
The present moment, when the film continues to be screened daily at Maratha Mandir and remains a cultural touchstone for Indian audiences and international tourists.

keyTakeAways: DDLJ is considered one of the greatest love stories in Indian cinema, resonating across generations due to its portrayal of love, tradition, and personal agency.
The film helped redefine Bollywood narratives by featuring Indians living abroad as central characters and addressing cultural identity and familial approval in a nuanced way.
It launched a new cinematic era in India by blending Western cultural influences with traditional Indian values, setting a template for future romantic blockbusters.
The on-screen pairing of Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol became a defining standard in Bollywood romance, influencing the industry’s romantic storytelling for decades.
The film's enduring popularity—still screened daily at Maratha Mandir in Mumbai—demonstrates deep cultural attachment and emotional resonance among Indian audiences.
While the film's gender politics and portrayal of Simran’s limited agency are now seen as outdated, its emotional core and romantic ideals continue to captivate viewers.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores the enduring cultural significance of the 1995 Bollywood film 'Diwale Dulhania Le Jayenge' (DDLJ), which continues to captivate Indian audiences nearly 30 years after its release. The film, directed by Aditya Chopra and starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, became a cultural touchstone during India’s early 1990s economic liberalization, capturing a nation’s yearning for global connection while honoring tradition. It introduced a new narrative in Indian cinema—centering on Indians living abroad and the conflict between personal love and familial expectations—while launching a lasting romantic standard for Bollywood. The film’s music, costume design, and emotional narrative have contributed to its timeless appeal. Today, it is still screened daily at the Maratha Mandir in Mumbai, where generations of Indians gather to experience it. Though some modern critics see the film's gender politics as outdated, its emotional resonance and cultural symbolism remain strong, illustrating how a film can transcend time and become a national identity marker.
title: Why a Bollywood classic about forbidden love still captivates Indian movie-goers 30 years on
